intro: Paepalanthus obtusifolius, commonly known as the woolly puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette of fleshy, woolly leaves that store water. The plant produces a tall flowering stem that bears numerous small, bell-shaped flowers, typically in shades of red or orange. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to high-altitude environments. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens.
